This is due in part to the growing importance of the executive branch and the rise of party politics, which has shifted attention away from the Senate's original purpose.

The Senate's modern role is primarily symbolic, serving as a placeholder for state legislatures when Congress is not in session. However, this role is increasingly redundant as state legislatures are more effective at representing their constituents. Moreover, the Senate's role in the legislative process has become increasingly overshadowed by the filibuster, a procedural tactic that allows senators to block bills without actually voting on them. This has made it difficult to enact necessary reforms and compromise on complex issues.
